conclusion: The problem involves understanding how shadows (A, B, C, D) of objects change in position and size when the light source moves backward.
There are four objects visible: a hat, a glove, a peach, and a calendar. Each object casts a shadow labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The shadow A is cast by the hat, shadow B by the glove, shadow C by the peach, and shadow D by the calendar.
The shadows are projected on the ground and are elongated due to the light source's position.
When a light source moves backward, the distance between the light source and the objects increases, which can affect the size and position of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will generally become longer because the angle of light hitting the objects becomes shallower.
The position of the shadows will shift further away from the objects as the light source moves backward.
The specific shape of each shadow (A, B, C, D) will still depend on the shape of the corresponding object.
